description: Calculate your total annual income based on your projected weekly pay.

assumptions: Assumes the target weekly pay stays strictly consistent throughout the timeframe.
Defaults to 52 weeks in a calendar year if calculating full-time equivalent without unpaid breaks.
insights: Using 52 weeks is mathematically inaccurate for hourly workers because it assumes zero unpaid sick days, holidays, or vacations over the entire year. 48 or 50 is a much safer estimation metric.
If your weekly pay fluctuates wildly (e.g., hospitality shifts), find your total pay over the last 4 weeks, divide by 4, and use that running average here.

faqs.q: Why is assuming 52 weeks of pay risky?
faqs.a: If you are strictly paid weekly based on hours, assuming 52 weeks means you are literally planning to work every single weekday without a single vacation day or sick day.

faqs.q: How do I calculate a short-term contract?
faqs.a: Change the 'Weeks Worked per Year' to however long the contract lasts. This will show you exactly what that specific contract will yield.

faqs.q: How many weeks are in a standard working year with holidays?
faqs.a: A standard European full-time contract implies roughly 46-47 actual working weeks, with the remainder being paid vacation. If you are hourly, use 47 to estimate realistic annual yield.

faqs.q: Why is the Monthly Average calculated by dividing by 12?
faqs.a: While you might be paid weekly, most fixed expenses (rent, utilities) occur on a monthly cadence. Dividing the annual total by 12 provides the safest monthly budgeting baseline.

faqs.q: What if my weekly pay includes overtime?
faqs.a: If you consistently work overtime, include it in your weekly average. However, doing so builds a budget dependent on working more than standard hours, which carries a high risk of burnout.
